Award.AbstractNarration:
Filaments, ridges, graphs, contours, and paths are examples of geometric objects in modern data analytic challenges. The development and the analysis of statistical methodology to tackle challenges related to such objects is the overarching goal of this project. In particular, the principal investigator and his collaborators will (i) develop statistical methodology and algorithms for the estimation of ridge lines and/or filamentary structure involving path smoothing methodologies. Here, paths are estimates of integral curves of gradients or of appropriate eigenvectors of Hessians. (ii) They will also develop dimension reduction methodology for subsequent clustering of high-dimensional data, where projection onto non-linear manifolds will be considered. Further goals are (iii) the adaptation of model selection methodologies for high-dimensional graphical models to incorporate spatial and temporal smoothness, and (iv) the investigation of commonalities and differences between statistical density/regression level set methodology and depth contour approaches. Besides the intrinsic geometric nature of the problems under consideration, geometry also comes into play via the choice of an appropriate distance measure, for instance.

This project will lead to new statistical methodologies underpinned by relevant theory, and to corresponding numerical algorithms in the area of geometric statistics. In this field of statistics, the objects of interest itself are genuinely geometrically motivated. One important guiding instance of a relevant scientific problem is the analysis of the cosmic web, which consists of locations of galaxies in the space. The web-like structure of these locations requires the use of nonstandard methodologies. Geometrically motivated objects also play a major role in several other scientific areas, such as medical imaging, fingerprint identification and remote sensing. The findings of this project will advance the field of statistics, and they will directly impact the relevant fields of application. The education of graduate and undergraduate students in a modern field of statistics is another important goal of this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project addressed the analysis of geometric objects, such as filaments, ridges, graphs, contours, and paths. Such objects play an important role in many practical applications of modern data challenges. For instance, the curves outlined by a medical image of blood vessels, or the curves that are formed by a road network in satelite images can be considered to be networks of filaments. The same can be said for the structure that arises in the cosmic web consisting of locations of galaxies (see attached image). Another instance of a geometric object is a contour. Contours play a major role in geology (contour plots) and the uncertainty inherent in such plots needs to be assessed. Contours also are of interest in ecology, where for instance the boundary (contour) delineating the range of a certain type of species is of importance. Ecologists have a keen interest in obtaining accurate estimates of such boundary contours based on the observed locations of individual animals. Yet another type of object addressed in this project is given by networks. Networks enjoy a high popularity within statistics but also in numerous fields of application. A prototype of a modern large social network is the internet, showing locations of individual servers (computers) around the world along with their links among each other.

The development and the analysis of statistical methodology to tackle challenges related to such objects was the overarching goal of this project. The project attempted to keep a balance between the development of methodology useful in practical applications (broader impact), and the theoretical investigations of the statistical behavior of these methods (intellectual metrits).

The principal investigator and his collaborators have achieved the general goals outlined above by developing (i) statistical methodology and algorithms for the estimation of networks of filaments and of contour lines; (ii) methodology to analyze networks by incorporating spatial information, and (iii) important probabilistic tools (so-called extreme value theory for non-stationary Gaussian processes). The probabilistic tools have been used in the development of supporting theory within this project, but they are important in their own right in the area of probability theory. The corresponding findings and results have been published in international statistics journals and at online portals (arXiv), and they have been disseminated directly to the relevant communities through presentations at invited seminar, and at national and international workshops and conferences.

The project also contributed to the visibility of the important specific subfield of statistics it has addressed. Evidence for this is provied by recent special invited lectures of the PI at the University of Leiden, Netherlands, and at the 3rd conference of the International Society of Nonparametric Statistics at Avignon, France. Both lectures addressed the statistical analysis of geometric objects, and presented results obtained in this project.

The project also contributed to the development of human resources. Three statistics PhD-students have been supported through this project (two of them already graduated). Moreover, eight undergraduate students have been exposed to modern areas of statistics through direct involvement in the project.

In summary, the project contributed statistical methodologies and algorithms of importance in many fields of applications, enhanced the core knowledge of statistics, and contributed significantly to the development of human resources in a field that takes a central position in the age of Data Science.
